name: History of the United States of America Part 3 Quiz | History | 10 Questions

questions.text: Theodore Roosevelt became president in 1901 after the assassination of president McKinley. His policy, which was a response to the nation's problems at the time, greatly affected the international standing of the U.S. What was the name of Roosevelt's policy?
questions.explanation:
Big Stick Policy.

	Through the policy, Roosevelt attempted to peacefully negotiate with foreign countries while at the same time threatening them with military power. Roosevelt is quoted as saying, "Speak softly, and carry a big stick".

questions.text: The Pure Food and Drug Act, as well as the Meat Inspection Act,were enacted in 1906 by Congress. What book by Upton Sinclair revealed information about health issues in US food production that led to the passage of these acts?
questions.explanation:
The Jungle.

	"The Jungle" portrays the lives of immigrants exposed to the unhealthy practices of the meat packing industry during the early 1900s. Sinclair was a journalist concerned with exposing corruption, and did many investigations for a newspaper in order to uncover the sanitary issues.

questions.text: The 17th Amendment to the US Constitution was passed in 1913. What did this amendment do?
questions.correct: Established the direct election of US Senators
options: Established the direct election of US Senators
Banned quartering of troops in private homes
questions.explanation:
Established the direct election of US Senators.

	Originally, the Constitution stated that senators were elected by state legislators. The amendment also allowed he governor to make temporary appointments for vacancies in Congress until an election could be held.

questions.text: World War One began in 1914. The United States did not enter until 1917. Which of the following powers was the United States allied with?
questions.explanation:
France.

	France was one of Allies along with the US, which fought against the Central Powers. The war lasted four years, proving to be one of the deadliest conflicts in history, killing over nine million.

questions.text: As tensions of Communism (and ideologies seen as related) increased, fear grew that it would spread to the US. Two anarchists known as Sacco and Vanzetti were arrested after an armed robbery. They were executed in 1927 due to their anarchist ideas. What was the name of this time period in which the world was scared of the spread of communism?
questions.explanation:
The Red Scare.

	Sacco and Vanzetti were convicted of the robbery with little evidence that they were even involved. There was even evidence to suggest that they were miles away from the scene of the crime when it happened.

questions.text: The Great Depression started in 1929 and lasted for many years. The American economy suffered greatly during the time period and many people were affected. Which of the following did NOT happen during the Great Depression?
options: International trade dropped by more then 50%
questions.explanation:
Interest rates more than doubled.

	President Roosevelt created many programs in the 1930s known as the New Deal that helped take the United Stated out of the Depression. One of the best known is the TVA (Tennessee Valley Authority), which allowed for the creation of many dams and power sources, strengthening the economy.

questions.text: In 1937 a German passenger airship caught fire in New Jersey, killing at least 35 people. What was the name of this disaster, in which there is widespread debate over the cause of the explosion?
questions.explanation:
Hindenburg.

	The disaster marked the end of the airship era. The Hindenburg was filled with hydrogen instead of helium, proving to be a disastrous mistake.

questions.text: World War Two began in 1939 but the US remained neutral until 1941. The United States entered the war because Japan had attacked a US naval base at Pearl Harbor. Where did this disaster occur?
questions.explanation:
Hawaii.

	America was unprepared for this attack and nearly 2,400 men were killed. The base and most of the naval ships were almost completely destroyed. America joined the war a day later.

questions.text: In 1945 World War Two ended when the United States dropped two atomic bombs on Japan. The first was dropped on Hiroshima. Where was the second dropped?
questions.explanation:
Nagasaki.

	The second bomb was dropped on August 9th killing more then 73,000. Japan surrendered on August 15, which officially became known as VJ Day (Victory Over Japan).

questions.text: After World War Two the American government attempted to aid Europe in war recovery efforts. What four year plan, officially known as the European Recovery Plan, sought to rebuild areas destroyed by the war and modernize Europe's economy?
questions.explanation:
Marshall Plan.

	The Marshall plan gave Europe 13 billion dollars to help rebuild its economy and prevent the spread of Communism, which at the time was particularly strong in France and Italy.
